What was the burden being imposed in Calder?

The burden I think was that the employer, when the employee invoked the power of that statute... and I think it's important to remember that under both of these statutes, it was an individual who invoked the power of them... but in the Calder case, when the employee told the employer that he wanted a day off for his religious reasons, then the employer had the duty to try to accommodate him taking that day off.
But that was a duty imposed... that was a duty imposed by the state, right?
That's correct.
And what... what duty is imposed by the state here?
Mayson's given... Mayson is told that his interest in not having his religious beliefs coerced after 16 years of employment has to be subordinated to the Mormon Church's right to do it.

Telling him he must accommodate his employer?
